posts.author: Demos
posts.content:
Here is a class combination that I didn't find in the old build search engine.  And before anyone asks, NO IT DOESN'T USE KAMAS.  The purpose of this build is have a good balance of offense and defense while using a spear.  While there are better weapons out there, I've found some pretty nice spears where I play and wanted to take advantage of them.  This build combines Monk and Assassin feats, and even with moderate gear, gets very respectable AC and AB numbers.  Note that this build wears robes only.

Here is what you get:

Offensive
High base AB of 47
Full array of combat feats (blind fight, improved knockdown, etc)
x4 crits
high base damage (1-8 + 16)
5d6 Death attack (treat as sneaks since the Death Attack DC will be very low)

Defensive
Monk speed
Improved Evasion
Improved Expertise
Improved Invisibility
Uncanny Dodge
Ghostly Visage

With +4 equipment (robes, ring, natural amulet, DEX+4 and WIS+4), AC is 45.  Pop on Improved Expertise and you are up to 55.  If you have Haste on, you're at 59 AC with Improved Expertise on and 50% concealment from Improved Invisibility.

With a +4 spear and STR+4 equipment, your AB is at 53.  You could easily walk around with Improved Expertise on all the time as your AB would still be 43.

The only downside is HP is a bit low for a melee toon at 366 without gear.  He is not your primary tank, but with the high AC and concealment, he could hold the line if needed while the main tank gets treatment.

Without further ado, I present the Spear Disciple:

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Heya Demos, back with an interesting build i see.

It kind of looks like my "shadow warrior" build but you use monk/assassin instead of shadowdancer to achieve all those nice passive effects like "improved evasion" in your build. I like how it is not a kama build and i like it more because he is strength-based. At high levels when perma-haste might be available he will also get a nice speed bonus from monk as well, since haste effects are multiplied in their case. Overall a nice and enjoyable build due to wm criticals and monk speed both! If i was about to make a suggestion, that would only be for your fortitude save, that is kind of weak for a warrior, so i would replace improved expertise with epic fortitude in a heartbeat. Regular expetise will suffice with this build since he has full tumble and both wisdom and dexterity bonuses to his ac.

Something else you could improve, although i am fairly sure you had your reason for this (perhaps the PW that you play in) is your skills. I would take all those points from heal and put it into UMD so that i could use any item or scroll. That's all and again kudos for an interesting build like this.

posts.author: Demos
posts.content:
Thanks Valerfor.  Swapping Improved Expertise for Epic Fortitude is a good suggestion.  Where I play, you won't find Dev Crit on most monsters and there are plenty of save boosters so my Fort save hasn't been an issue but your suggestion is certainly a good tweak for other places.  I think skills are always adjustable...again where I play, there are only a few magical items that UMD is applicable for (no high level scrolls are available for example) so I only took a modest number of ranks in UMD.

Some people will say maxing both Spot and Listen are overkill so there is another area to customize.  If True Seeing is readily available (not where I play except from other players), I would swap those skills for others, like Set/Disable Traps and Open Locks.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Maybe this might help.  ImpInvis cannot be breached and its concealment dispelling is linked to other spell effects which may also be part of the target's temporary skin.

But you should be confused by a quirk in the game like this.  The mechanics of dispelling ImpInvis's concealment has little reliance on the caster level. It's the way that the effect is linked to others that determines the probability of dispel.  That means a scroll of ImpInvis (7) will amount to just about the same results (...as an asn 9 feat version) and can be used as many times per day with UMD as the number of scrolls in inventory.

Now, i understand that the concealment brought by the Improved Invisibility is undispellable, which should be a bug of NWN, as the wikia state below.
http://nwn.wikia.com/wiki/Improved_invisibility


But the link you provided give me more confusion.
"For this calculation the effective level can be one of five things, checked in the following order."
By "effective level ", i think it mean the target's "creator's effective level", as in this equation.
"1d20 + dispel's caster level vs. 12 + creator's effective level."
But as i follow the article:
"Zero, if the effect being dispelled is one of the following types of effects while attempting to dispel all effects."
".....
concealment
see invisibility
true seeing
....."
From the above list, my conduction is that when casting a dispel spell on a creature with true seeing, the equation will be:
"1d20 + dispel's caster level >= 12 + 0"
So, the game make it easier to dispel the above list effect? I don't understand the reason behind this, especially when concealment effect is in the list, which should be supernatural effect and not dispellable.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Vecho wrote:
So, the game make it easier to dispel the above list effect? I don't understand the reason behind this, especially when concealment effect is in the list, which should be supernatural effect and not dispellable.

 
It's both complicated and unpredictable which is why I've done a certain amount of testing myself.  After testing several hundred permutations of combined spell effects applied I was able to glean NO direct consequence between caster level and dispelling concealment.

I am not sure where you've gotten the idea that concealment is anything but a magical effect applied by the ImpInvis impact spell script.  It is the linkage to other effects that make its dispellability difficult to assess and predict.  If it were either supernatural or extraordinary, EffectConcealment(50) would have been declared one of those effect subtypes within the script and it has not... not within vanilla resources anyway.
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
But really, this discussion should be carried on probably as a general topic since the mechanics of applying and removing the concealment effect is not a build consideration posed by the author, just a member's comment.  If you would like to extend the discussion further (it's interesting but misplaced), PM me and I'll try to move the effects discussion into another topic just in case this inflates beyond what is reasonable to expect within the OP's scope.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Theophilus Fist wrote: ↑
May 21, 2022
Went back to him earlier this month and just finished "Sands of Fate 1" with him getting to level 32.
Still fun to play.  I am looking at a couple of tweaks in future plays:

1 - Dev Crit.  He's generating a lot of crits as is, with 160+ damage, but for high level monsters, insta-kills are preferable.
2 - Drop STR from 16 to 14 and bump CON from 10-14.  80 HP & +2 Fort save
What are you thinking of dropping to accommodate the 4 feats you'll need for Dev Crit (given that Monk gets free Cleave, you'll still need Power Attack, Great Cleave, Overwhelming and Devastating Crits)? Improved Expertise and Epic Toughness seem simple enough choices, but that still leaves 2.

If you drop 2 Great Strengths, that leaves 30 STR - or 28 STR if you take your second tweak, which is -1 (or -2) AB and means your Dev Crit DC will drop to 40 (still respectable) or 39 (getting a bit dodgy for my liking).

Alternatively, you could drop Epic Prowess (-1AB) and 1 Great Strength, still leaving you with a STR of 30 if you start with a STR of 15 and a CON of 12.

Unless you had something else in mind?

Cheers

posts.author: 2hpnotiq
posts.content: Hmm anyway to shuffle stuff around and build this without Quick to Master and come out to close same build?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
There is, but you will lose 1AB due to having to take 3 more levels of Monk or Assassin before you can take WM, which would also impact on later skill dumps (in that they wouldn't be so regular). The feat I'd lose would be Improved Expertise.of the 43 lost skill points, you could lose the 26 points in Heal, but the other 17 would be your call. You can, in most cases, keep the stats the same with other races, other than Half-Orc, where you'd also lose 2 points in CHA (so you'd have to put 1 more point in UMD to keep the same result). If you want to use a spear, obviously don't chose Halfling or Gnome, who can't (it being a large weapon).

Hope this helps

Cheers
